par.text: Beryllium is a grey metal, hard and brittle at room temperature. In contact with air it becomes covered by a thin protective coat of oxide (BeO). Powdered
ignites when heated. It does not react with water.

Beryllium was discovered in 1797 by a French chemist Louis Nicolas Vauquelin. In 1828 beryllium was isolated independently by Friedrich Wöhler and Antoine Bussy. The name beryllium is derived from the mineral beryl - a compound of beryllium. The Greek word
means 'gem'. Beryllium and its compounds, especially when powdered, are highly poisonous.
